Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: How say the scribes that Christ is the son of David?—How come they to give it out that Messiah is to be the son of David?

Mark the impression on the people, in whose presence (Mark 12:37) the Pharisees were confounded.

Archibald T. Robertson: He contents himself with pointing out a difficulty, in the solution of which lay the key to the whole problem of His person and work" (Swete).
The scribes all taught that the Messiah was to be the son of David...But the rabbis had overlooked the fact that David in Psalms 110:1 called the Messiah his Lord also" (Swete).
The deity and the humanity of the Messiah are both involved in the problem" (Swete).
John Gill: Not that Christ meant to deny or invalidate the truth of this; for the Messiah was certainly to be the son of David, and was; but he wanted to know, inasmuch as they commonly said, and instructed the people to believe, and it was in general believed by them, that he was David's son, how they could reconcile this to his being the Lord of David."
How they could give out, that he was only and merely the Son of David, when he was David's Lord.
This question seems to be put upon that, with another along with it, how then doth David in spirit call him Lord?

This question highlights the key problem of understanding Jesus' person and work, involving both his deity and humanity. Jesus does not deny the truth of the Messiah being the son of David, but he challenges the scribes to reconcile this with the fact that David calls the Messiah his Lord. The people were confounded by this response.
